page.title: 19Tourism and the canal
page.content: The Ellesmere Canal has influenced the development of our landscape, but, surprisingly, it is still influencing the area. The LMS closed all the local canals in 1944 although the Shrewsbury line had been derelict for some time. The last operators, Peates of Maesbury Mill had changed to lorries and it was only in 1954 that the Llangollen Canal was adopted as a water feeder. Early cruising enthusiasts such as Tom Rolt publicised the canals and traffic has grown to make this one of the most popular canals in Britain. This may have led to the growth of holiday homes and to an influx of retiring couples. The effects of this can be seen at Lower Frankton where locals have found house too pricey at recent auctions. People are worried that, on retirement, they may have to leave the village they have always lived in.
